title: Advertising and Society
requirements:
UGEC2638 is double-coded with COMM2840. 
Not for GCOM; COMM Majors; and students who have taken COMM2840. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2638 is double-coded with COMM2840.) In this course, students will analyze real life campaigns to understand major effects of advertising in everyday life. Students will examine topics like materialism and commercialization of friendship to see how advertising persuade consumers through subtle uses of messages. They will also decode the formation and shifting of values promoted by Government and green campaigns. The course will help students distinguish between authentic and mediated reality regarding topics on artificial perfection of body image, sexual objectification and gender stereotyping.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will:    1.     Identify the multifaceted effects of mass-mediated advertising messages along the dimensions of subliminal messaging, infusion of constructed meanings, and mediation of reality. 2.     Recognize the impacts of advertising on personal and psychological development. 3.     Critically analyze advertising messages and motivations. 4.     Investigate beyond the seemingly superficial phenomenon created by advertising into deeper issues related to living attitude and social values. 5.     Develop a curiosity towards real life campaigns that promote meaningful causes that benefit citizens in Hong Kong.
syllabus: I. SUBLIMINAL PERSUASION             Week 1: Subliminal Messaging and Materialism   This week will introduce briefly all three sections and emphasis more specifically on subliminal persuasion, using materialism, luxury branding in China as examples. China has replaced Japan as the second strongest economic power in the world in 2012. It has also surpassed the US to become the second largest luxury brand market in 2009, spending of $9.4 billion and accounting for 27.5% of total global sales of luxury brands in the world. The invasion of luxury brands will inevitably alter the spending culture in China. Luxury brand ads hint subtly that consumers using them belong to a higher social group in the society. Students will discuss the subliminal indicators of luxury brand ads and their effects on attitudes towards social status in the society.    Week 2: Commercialization of Friendship in Social Networking Sites   Social networking sites are dominating the media landscape among young people. Many viral ads are circulated through the disguise of sincere recommendations from friends, who actually share information for an incentive. This class will look into the core of this issue: should friendship be commercialized for personal gains?   Week 3: Properties, Personal Loan Ads and Wealth   The recent waves of glamorized Hong Kong properties ads disseminated in China led to grave consequences in raising the prices of flats in Hong Kong. The property ads In Hong Kong shape unrealistic desires in viewers to own a flat that demands a lifetime of hard earned salaries. Personal loan ads encourage a supposedly free life of spending with no responsibility. This lesson will discuss the dynamics of these subliminal messages in affecting one’s decision about how to spend his / her money.   Week 4: Political Campaigns and Elections   The presence of political campaigns in commercial media becomes prevalent these days due to the rise of democratization in the election process. This lesson will look into the various tactics and subliminal strategies used and manipulated in political advertising and its effects on public participation in election.   II. MEDIATION OF REALITY   Week 5: Beauty Ads and Body Image   This lesson will start with an in-depth look at the concept of mediation of reality, using studies conducted in Hong Kong that relate beauty and slimming product / service ads to a negative self-perceived body image in both men and women. Teenagers, in particular, are finding their self in their growing years by comparing themselves to the models in the ads. The gap between the idealized self and actual self creates frustrations among many. To bridge the gap, some fall for crash diets and some for desperate acts of plastic surgeries.   Week 6: Stereotypical Sex Ads and Gender Roles   This lesson looks into the relationship between commoditization and objectification of the body and the resultant stereotypical roles played by men and women. Students will be challenged to live beyond the fixed roles narrowly defined and presented in the pseudo-reality.   Week 7: Tutor King / Queen Ads and Education   The educational system in Hong Kong requires students to acquire incessant training and upgrading. Many tutors chanced this opportunity to create fast track learning to success by advertising their success rate of getting a student to obtain an As. This form of promotion alters students’ mentality to learning. Tutors acting as opinion leaders in ads create a trend of commercialized education.   Week 8: A “Copycat” Culture   “Copycat” China refers not only to the many cases of copying of products but also the imitation of ideas and other intellectual properties in China. Advertising is an industry that is keen on creativity, the very core element that sustains the industry. Piracy will suffocate the creative industry in the long run. Students will scan the creative landscape in China and learn to identify the seemingly original creative reality.   III. INFUSION OF CONSTRUCTED MEANINGS   Week 9: Freedom of Speech and the Press  This class will start examining the idea about meaning and value driven advertising/ advocacy. Recent cases show that advertising is affecting the press in Hong Kong and the Mainland has been censoring a lot of ads online and outdoor. What is the value of commercial speech? How much would the commercial speech be compromised? Will the censorship erode creativity, global branding strategy and business development? Students will investigate the longstanding struggle of the protection of speech in Hong Kong and the mainland.   Week 10: Globalizing and Standardization   Global brands launched by global advertising agencies bring about their unique culture from the country-of-origin into a foreign country. For a global brand to be successfully adopted by local citizens, the agencies need to accommodate the traditional culture. However, the global influence for standardization sometimes surpasses localization, resulting in a pervasive infusion of foreign values. The balance and consideration of both cultures are the center of discussion in this lesson. A few global campaigns around the world will be presented to demonstrate the delicate balance between globalization and localization.   Week 11: “Anti” Campaigns and Social Movements   This lesson will look into the value-driven impact and of Public Service Announcements (PSAs), including the anti-smoking, anti-drug and anti-AIDS campaigns on society. The lesson will also focus on the development, planning and execution of those campaigns. It is the purpose of the lesson to raise the awareness of the students in these cause advertising campaigns.   Week 12: Earth Hour, Outdoor Light Pollution and other Green Campaigns   Greenpeace and other environmental protection groups have been working on major campaigns to improve the living conditions of the world. A few successful green campaigns will be discussed in class to reveal their value shifting strategies.   Week 13: Food, Drug Ads and Public Health   World Health Organization has established the strong tie between advertising of high fat, salt and sugar (HFSS) food and obesity. While UK has exercised blanket ban of food advertising to children and many other countries following suit, the Broadcasting Authority in Hong Kong has only advised five cases in the past four years regarding HFSS food ads to children. This lesson will investigate the difficult path to policy change in the business sector in Hong Kong. Advertising of all medicinal products in Hong Kong is strictly controlled by the Undesirable Medical Advertisements Ordinance (Cap 231) (the UMAO). Section 3 of the UMAO provides for an outright prohibition against the publication of 'any advertisement likely to lead to the use of any medicine … for the purpose of treating … or preventing' any disease, disorder or abnormal physical state. However, some prominent direct-to-consumer prescription drug ads are produced and broadcasted in Hong Kong recently. DTC drug advertising will change the traditional beliefs towards doctor-patient relationship and the demand of name-brand drugs at the expense of generic or equally effective drugs. Students will explore the Campaigns of Gardasil and Cervarix to find out their use of Government bodies as façade to lure the public to consult doctors about the drugs.

requirements:

Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum) )
description: (UGEC2653 is double-coded with ANTH2310.) This course looks at the relationship between gender and culture, by comparing women and men in societies with different modes of production and social organization. Through analysing gender roles, enculturation process, kinship, division of labour by gender, power and control and social development, students will understand how culture influences the concept of gender and its related behaviour among human groups.

title: Indian Cultures and Society
requirements:
UGEC2655 is double-coded with ANTH2324. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2324 or 3324. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2655 is double-coded with ANTH2324.) This course is an anthropological introduction to contemporary India, its social life and diverse cultures. India is home to more than a billion people, who look differently, speak various languages, practice different religions, and have distinct rituals, cuisines, and music. It is one of the world’s powers with global economic, political, and intellectual influence. Moreover, it shares important ties in the sphere of philosophy, religion, and medicine with China and other Asian societies. Therefore, students will learn about India’s place both in the world and the Asian region, including its ties with Hong Kong. Students will also develop an understanding of the country’s diversity and complex social phenomena such as kinship, communalism, caste system, tribe, third gender, and class. We will discuss pressing issues and theoretical debates related to globalization, sexuality, social movements, religious conflicts, public health, environment, and labor, and how these issues have been shaped by post-colonial politics and current transnational processes.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to do the following:    understand and analyze the diversity of Indian society in terms of region, caste, class, religion, language, gender, and other sociocultural divisions    identify and compare the main ideas of various schools of philosophy and religion that originated in the Indian subcontinent    describe and give examples of the everyday life of Indian women and men, as well as hijras, and other persons who identify differently    explain the impact of India’s colonial history on its modern society    examine the role of popular culture, political processes, and the global economy in the lives of Indians in India and abroad    explain the cultural influences of India on the Asian region and the world    critically assess the academic literature, news, and public discourses about various aspects of the Indian society
syllabus: Indian population in terms of linguistic, cultural, and regional diversity; Indo-European and Dravidian languages as the major linguistic groups in India; Differences between South and North India, special positions of the North East, Kashmir, and the Andaman islands   Caste system (varna, jati), Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (indigenous groups) The division of the Indian society into castes and those considered to be outside the caste system. History and contemporary practices related to caste discrimination and privilege; the place of the indigenous groups known as tribals or Adivasi   hijra (third gender) Communities of people who identify neither men nor women   India’s independence, Partition (of India and Pakistan) The significance  of 1947 Indian independence from the British colonial rule, the establishment of India and Pakistan, and its impact on present-day India   Hinduism, Islam, Sikhism, Jainism, religious festivals (Diwali, oli) Different religions as well as their rituals, beliefs, festivals, political representations, and family practices   Arranged marriage, extended family, modern femininities and masculinities The significance of family relations and arranged marriages in India; different models of being a woman and being a man in India, specifically Indians imagine themselves as “traditional” or “modern” women and men   Yoga, Ayurveda, Indian sports and medicine History and contemporary practices of Indian health traditions of Yoga and Ayurveda; how Indians take care of their health and body, different sports they play   Curry and other Indian foods Regional differences in foods; the impact of colonial history on contemporary habits and preferences in eating, cooking and dining   Bollywood and Indian popular culture The cultural, economic, and political importance of the Bollywood industry; other regional film industries in India   Migration, Indians in Hong Kong Indian diasporas around the world; the history and current processes of migration of Indians to Hong Kong; the experiences of locally born Indians in Hong Kong

title: Working Cultures – Understanding Work in the 21st Century
requirements:
UGEC2656 is double-coded with ANTH2550. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2550.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2656 is double-coded with ANTH2550.) Work is a central practice and system of human production, innovation, social organization, and cooperation. Focusing on the work-place as 'working cultures', this course offers an anthropological perspective to understand how work is a matter of place, time, power, and meanings. We will further explore how current social, technological, and cultural transformations of work can be understood across places, in their historic continuities and disruptions. Each week the course analyzes, discusses, and rethinks a key concept in the anthropology of work: Class, time, race, gender, value, craft, ownership, creativity, autonomy, discipline, etc. Through reading contemporary ethnographies of different workplaces and circumstances, students will learn the analysis and theory of work in familiar or unexpected forms, as well as in different organizational settings from the office, factory, workshop, home, to online platforms. This course will further give the students the tools to systematically connect their own observations of work to writing about working cultures.

title: Ethnographies of Japan
requirements:
UGEC2657 is double-coded with ANTH2327.
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2327.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix
description: (UGEC2657 is double-coded with ANTH2327.) This course provides an introduction to contemporary Japanese society and culture. In the popular imagination, Japan occupies a complex and often contradictory position. It is home to futuristic anime and an aging population, picturesque villages and dolphin hunts, high-end cameras and the widespread use of quaint fax machines. Engaging with anthropological literature, students will learn to analyze, discuss, and write about various issues and cultural features of Japan, including youth, popular culture, self, family, labor, medicine, and health. An overarching theme will be how Japanese culture and society is changing in the transition to a highly aged society. We will examine persistent cultural patterns as well as the emergence of new forms of social life as residents of Japan grapple with smaller families, precarity, migration, and a rising population of older people. Students will learn how to apply theoretical concepts from anthropology and think critically about Japanese culture and its portrayals in the media. The ethnographic approaches and theoretical perspectives covered in this class will be applicable to other cultural contexts. Since Hong Kong, China, and Korea are following Japan’s path of population aging, this course provides an opportunity to explore cultural issues that have a local and regional significance.
outcome: Students will acquire a robust knowledge of contemporary Japanese society and culture. They will develop an understanding of cultural diversity within Japan and the broad shifts associated with population aging.  Students will gain the ability to apply anthropological theory to analyze Japanese society and culture. In conjunction, students will learn to critically evaluate scholarly and media portrayals of Japan. These critical faculties will also be relevant for understanding their own or other societies in daily life as well as for future anthropological studies.  Students will develop their writing skills. In addition to conventional academic essays, students will learn to write ethnographically about a specific site. Through writing, students will gain skills in communication of their own observations and perspectives on cultural features. These skills can be used for further academic study as well as personal and professional life.
syllabus: Part I: Foundations of Japanese Culture and Society Week 1. What is Japanese culture? This lesson introduces the concept of culture and gives a brief history on the sociocultural and geographical boundaries of Japan.Week 2. Foundational Works This lesson provides students with an  introduction to early major writings about Japan, including early European and American visitors to Japan.Week 3. Myths of Japaneseness This session will examine of common media tropes about Japan and the pseudo-scholarly genre of writing known as Nihonnjinron. It explores forms of ethnocentricism, conceptions of cultural uniqueness, and nationalism in post WWII Japan.Week 4. Traditions and Inventions This session  focuses on the ways that traditions created and how people use them to give meaning to life. Through a discussion of bushido, the class will illuminate the recent invention of traditions popularly considered ancient and timeless in Japan.Week 5. Health and the Body The session provides a conceptual overview of how people in Japan understand their bodies, health, and illness. Particular attention will be paid to longevity and issues involved in aging.Week 6. Gift-giving and Ritual An exploration of situational, lifecycle, and calendar-based gift-giving and ritual in contemporary Japan. II. The Life Cycle in an Aging Japan Week 7. Love, Marriage, and Children This session provides an overview of romantic relationships, including non-heteronormative relationships, and reasons for low fertility in Japan. Romance in late life will also be part of the discussion.Week 8. Childhood and Schooling Focusing on preschool through high school, this session examines the ways children are taught to become adults in Japanese society.Week 9. Cute and Otaku This class explores  the origins of subcultures in Japan and how they are co-opted by the state and companies. It will highlight the ways that young people’s participation in these subcultures receives blame for low fertility.Week 10. Labor, Precarity, and Class This session is an examination of the changes in Japanese labor following WWII in relation to security, gender, and socioeconomic class. It will highlight how precarious working conditions lead individuals to delay or avoid marriage and having children.Week 11. Gender Students will learn about how gender intersects with family, work, and social roles. This session will highlight conventional roles of the male “salaryman” and the housewife, paying attention to female caregiving for older family members.Week 12. Aging and the End of Life This session examines the experiences of late life ideals for death .Week 13. Atomic Radiation and the Plight of Older People after Fukushima A broad discussion of Japan complicated relationship with radioactive decay, including atomics bombs, Godzilla, and the meltdown in Fukushima. Particular attention will be paid to case of aging survivors of the atomic bombs and older people’s communities displaced after the disasters following the earthquake on 11.3.2011.

title: Culture and Business
requirements:
UGEC2662 is double-coded with ANTH2510. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2510. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2662 is double-coded with ANTH2510.)  Culture is ubiquitous in every aspect of societies, including how we do business. This course will examine the role of culture in contemporary business and study work and management in industrial societies anthropologically. Students will be introduced to the cultural logics of business practices, particularly business operations, organization and management through ethnographic explorations of different cultures, locales and sociohistorical settings. The aims of the course are twofold. First, it reveals cultural aspects and the cultural mechanisms of business. It shows the significance of culture in the business world, as well as the cultural significance of business. Second, it attempts to put anthropology into business practice. It demonstrates to students how anthropological knowledge and methodologies can be applied to business operations and help to achieve business goals. By examining the themes including but not limited to the indoctrination of work ethics, labor relations, gender and racial issues in the workplace, capitalism and its discontents, and responses to and actions upon market capitalism in terms of both production and consumption, the course attends to these Sustainable Development Goals: No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17).
outcome: After the completion of this course, students will:  Understand and appreciate the cultural dimensions of business operations and organization in different historical, political, and social settings;  Acquire the necessary ethnographic skills to study diverse aspects of business operations and organization;  Be able to rethink and challenge the existing assumptions regarding business practices in the modern world;  Gain the analytical tools to examine issues of over-consumption, over-production, dispossession, oppression, and other relevant discontent under global capitalism;  Be able to examine critically the role SDGs could play in addressing disparities and injustices in the world;  Understand the importance of building a more inclusive, equal and diverse society.
syllabus: The course is structured in three parts. Part I Culture in Business explores the cultural dimensions of workplaces and corporate management. We begin with an overview of the temporal and spatial reconfigurations since industrialization in order to discern modern work ethics, followed by explorations of dynamics in the workplace. Next, we will explore discourses in shaping corporate operations and management, and consider (and challenge) the ideas of economization, maximization, auditing and accountability. This part decodes life in business settings, and practices in corporations. Part II Business Ventures in the Globalizing World situates the discussions in current trends of capitalism. We will look into what makes us buy and spend, and how traditional values and modern business practices mingle. It raises the question of whether we are really emancipated under the fashion of decentralization by exploring the gig economy and the phenomenon of self-enterprising. We will also examine how we can build a more inclusive, diverse and equal society by finding a new way out from the existing business ideologies and practices. Part III Anthropology and the Business World discusses how to apply anthropology in business settings, looking into how and why anthropology and anthropologists are important to the private sector, and broadly speaking, to the modern capitalist world. The course concludes by contemplating whether business is really business. Overall, through the examinations of how we are taught to work, produce, and buy, the imperative of gender and racial stereotypes in the workplace, turns in capitalism and the rise of new economies and the pertinent social and cultural phenomena, the course addresses the following Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): No Poverty (SDG#1), Gender Equality (SDG#5), Decent Work and Economic Growth (SDG#8), Reduced Inequalities (SDG#10), Responsible Consumption and Production (SDG#12), and Partnerships for the Goals (SDG#17). Core topics: Week 1         Course Introduction Week 2         Seeing Business Anthropologically (SDGs 17) Part I          Culture in Business Week 3         Space, Time and Work Ethics (SDGs 8, 10) Week 4         Gender, Race/Ethnicity, and Communication in the Workplace (SDGs 5, 8, 10) Week 5         Corporatization, Economization and Maximization (SDGs 1, 8, 10, 12) Week 6         Audit Culture and Accountability (SDGs 8) Week 7         Mid-term Test Part II         Business Ventures in the Globalizing World Week 8         The Making of Consumers (SDGs 10, 12) Week 9         Fieldtrip to a Social Enterprise/ a Social Innovation Project/ an exhibition about reindustrialization in Hong Kong Week 10       The Gig Economy and Self-enterprising (SDGs 1, 8, 10) Week 11       Ethical-Political Consumerism and Social Entrepreneurialism (SDGs 1, 5, 8, 10, 12, 17) Part III        Anthropology and the Business World Week 12       Applying Anthropology to Business Practice (SDGs 10, 17) Week 13       Conclusion: Is Business Really Business?

title: Sports and Culture
requirements:
UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2390.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2664 is double-coded with ANTH2390.)This course will examine the role and importance of sports in different societies and cultures, in the present and the past. Sports are often thought of as trivial, or as unimportant games to amuse young people. But in the wealthiest countries, sports represent huge portions of GDP and are important topics of daily conversation. Almost half the world watched the 2010 football/soccer World Cup. Sports have been compared to religions in their ability to unite people and to inspire fanatical devotion.The academic study of sports is interdisciplinary, with contributions from psychologists, historians, gender studies scholars, sociologists and anthropologists. This course will take an interdisciplinary approach while emphasizing anthropology’s focus on culture, on the experience of participants, and on both symbolic and political-economy aspects of sports. Topics will include Race and Performance, Sports and Rituals, Sports as Moral Education, Gender and Sexuality in Sport, Sports and Nationalism, Globalization of Sport, the Olympics, and Sports Stars and the Media. Students will be expected to do a research project for the course.

title: Social Media and Culture
requirements:
UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540. 
Not for Anthropology Majors; and students who have taken ANTH2540. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2665 is double-coded with ANTH2540.) This course addresses the ways in which social media and other related interactions in cyberspace have become a central element in the everyday lives of humans across the globe in the 21st Century. Our modern lives are now largely interwoven with digital technologies that have not only changed our own cultures, but also have brought forth new cultural forms through mobile phone technologies, networked “smart”-products, and cultural groupings only possible through digital means. The course approaches the anthropology of these digital cultures through its main themes—the transformation and expansion of social media, social research online, the intermixing of our online and offline lives, critical social issues of online lives, and the question of posthumanism. These themes are addressed explicitly in the course, and are also the subtexts of the different lectures, readings, and project work. Students will learn the techniques of online fieldwork and referencing. They will explore a diverse array of new ethnographies on social media: on gender, political movements, online dating, hacking, and gaming culture. These ethnographies also serve to model online social research and provide examples of methodology and design. The social consequences of cyberspace are addressed in the topics of internet pornography, addiction, surveillance, activism, and social networking. Gender and identity issues are a continuous theme throughout the course, highlighting how online lives accentuate already existing dynamics. Hong Kong connections to these subjects will also be critically discussed, often drawing on topical themes presented on blogs and forums. Students will learn of the philosophical questions of posthumanism and the nature of technologically mediated human culture. This serves as a philosophical ballast to the course allowing students to reflect personally on their own experiences and how technology has and will continue to shape their lives. The role of anthropology in understanding and capturing human culture in this context anchors on the investigation of how technology is possibly making us ‘more’ human than previous forms of cultural life.

title: Hong Kong Education Policy and Society
requirements: Not for students majoring in programmes offered by Faculty of Education; not for CLED and ELED Majors. Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to discuss and facilitate students to reflect education issues, policies and practices in Hong Kong. By applying sociological and political concepts and theories, the course will critically analyze current education issues and its development. This course will help students to understand and reflect on the interplay between politics, society and education system and its effect. It aims at equip students with a broader and deeper understanding of Hong Kong education policies and education system.

title: Interpersonal Violence
requirements:
UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2200.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2680 is double-coded with SOWK2200.) The purposes of this course are to provide students a basic understanding of violence that takes place in our daily life in the contexts of intimate relationship, family, school and community and to arouse their consciousness of contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice. Various concepts and theories of violence will be introduced to explore the nature, causes, consequences and trends of violence in different aspects of life. Emphasis will be placed on the issues of interpersonal violence in contemporary societies. Social policy and provisions to prevent and eliminate interpersonal violence will also be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:1.      Critically examine the contemporary perspectives, concepts and theories on interpersonal violence.2.    Analyze causes and consequences of interpersonal violence in different contexts.3.      Apply and integrate interdisciplinary theories of violence to evaluate current policy and strategies on tackling violence.4.      Reflect on ways to combat violence and help to promote a peaceful environment.5.      Appreciate the contemporary values of equality, human rights and social justice.
syllabus: 1.      Common misunderstanding and myths of interpersonal violence.2.      Contemporary perspectives and theories of violence from anthropology, education, medical science, politics, psychology, sociology and social work.3.      Nature, causes, consequences and trends of interpersonal violence.4.      The needs of victims and perpetrators of interpersonal violence.5.      Risk and protective factors of violence at personal, family, school, community and policy levels.6.      Issues of violence in regard to different genders, ages, classes, sexual orientations and cultures.7.      Current social policy and prevention programs on interpersonal violence.

title: Globalization and Politics
requirements:
UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.
Not for Government and Public Administration Majors; and students who have taken GLSD2301, GPAD2355 or UGEC2352.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2683 is double-coded with GPAD2355.)  This course introduces undergraduate students to the key concepts, theoretical frameworks, and main political discussions/reflections related to globalization. Globalization itself is introduced in a broad sense not limited by the economic aspect but a common experience of social change. For example, global environmental challenges, the common threat of nuclear crisis, the controversy between sovereignty and human rights, and the North-South divide. With both the historical and thematic perspectives, the class engages students with most recent research and debate on the topic. On the one hand, the class encourages students to relate their own experiences and observations in their own societies to digest what globalization is and what its impacts are. On the other hand, it also leads them to reflect on politics and social development in their own societies, in the context of globalization.

title: Social Work and Cultural Diversity
requirements:
UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2202.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2684 is double-coded with SOWK2202.)  This course provides students with fundamental and systematic knowledge on issues related to ethnic and cultural diversity. Apart from introducing contemporary theories and conceptual perspectives about cultural sensitivity and cultural intelligence, this course will also highlight major discourses and challenges concerning access, equity, social inclusiveness, cultural assimilation and integration which have substantial impact on ethnic minorities as well as social harmony. Through participation in small group projects, guided community tours, and face-to-face interaction with different ethnic groups, students will be able to develop an awareness of the differences in values, beliefs, life-style and interpersonal relatedness between themselves and people of other ethnic background. Basic skills, knowledge and attitude required of cultural intelligence, equal-opportunity legislations, social policies, service provision in meeting the needs of ethnic minorities, and measures to promote mutual acceptance and social inclusiveness will be discussed.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1.            Acquire knowledge of the key concepts and theoretical perspectives of multiculturalism, related social policies and service delivery system; 2.            Apply an intercultural perspective to understand the struggles, challenges and socio-cultural barriers of ethnic groups in Hong Kong. 3.            Evaluate the impact of culture on individuals and/or groups’ values, beliefs, behaviours, attitudes, preferences and life pursuits; 4.            Develop awareness in cultural sensitivity and acquire cultural competence as well as intercultural intelligence

title: Social Innovation and Social Change for Good
requirements:
UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2204.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2686 is double-coded with SOWK2204.)  This course prepares students to learn from the emerging practices of social innovations in tackling with challenges in social, economic, cultural and political development in Hong Kong, the Greater China region and beyond. Students will acquire analysis, knowledge and strategies of social innovations, the processes of social change in creating social values. The scope of social innovations includes that of social entrepreneurs or social innovators in NGOs, communities, social movements, non-profit organizations, and business as well as the public sector. The course will examine cases of social innovations that have catalyzed important positive social change through the market, the nonprofit sector, the community, the public sector as well as the spaces among those four sectors. Experiential learning will be integrated along the course delivery, such as programmme visits, dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users. Students are encouraged to experience these operations, so as to analyze the development issues, the social values and innovations in offering practical solutions to poverty and social inequalities, unemployment and livelihood, civic and community engagement, fair trade as well as sustainable development. The course will provide inspirations as well as know-hows for students who are concerned about the articulation of local with global and regional issues and like to develop innovative actions to change the society for good.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Realise how social innovations work to target social issues, creating social values through innovative strategies in various sectors as well as cross sectoral collaboration; ·         Recognize the basic know-hows of social innovation such as design thinking, community or civic engagement, collaboration, prototyping and lean start-up; ·         Apprehend how social innovation leverage their work and impact to catalyze changes in the broader community, economy or political sphere. ·         Critically evaluate how social innovation can fulfil the objectives of coping with the challenges in the social, economic, cultural and political spheres. ·         Acquire personal experience and prepare to taking own responsibilities as global citizen and ready to be social innovator / social entrepreneur in tackling the local, regional and global development challenges.

title: Mission-driven Social Enterprise
requirements:
UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203. 
Not for Social Work Majors; and students who have taken SOWK2203. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2693 is double-coded with SOWK2203.) This course introduces to students the field of mission-driven social enterprise, which aims to achieve a balance between meaningful social returns as well as sustainable or competitive financial returns through their products, services and other business practices. Through examining the best practices in social entrepreneurship, it also stimulates students to explore how social enterprise can affect policy and facilitate system change. Experiential learning elements such as visiting social enterprises and having dialogue with social entrepreneurs, staff members or service users will be arranged in order to let students experience its operation, understand its practice as well as to enable students in realizing its possibilities in offering solutions to education, healthcare, environment, workforce development, international development and other societal issues. The course is valuable to students who may want to design or lead a mission-driven social enterprise, or want to contribute time and energy to help build the social sector through this emerging field.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to ·         Understand how social entrepreneurs work to blend disparate goals, how and why social enterprises successfully fuse purpose and personal passion in business, and how visions and values are embedded in organizational culture; ·         Be familiar with a variety of approaches and tools to measure organizational performance and social impact of social enterprise. ·         Examine the key methods, strategies and models for social enterprises to succeed; ·         Understand the dimensions and models of social entrepreneurship and the strategies on fundraising, financial management, opportunity seeking, social marketing, alliance building, etc. ·         Apprehend how social enterprises leverage their work and impact to influence policy and the community; Critically evaluate how social enterprise can fulfil the objectives of meeting economic, ecological and social needs.

title: Youth Problem in Modern Society
requirements:
Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken SOCI2110.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course explores some of the major issues concerning the role of the youth and the problems confronting them in modern society. The nature of the conventional wisdom of the “youth problem” is critically examined, with the help of concepts and theories in sociology and related fields. By the end of the course, students are expected to gain more understanding of the nature of the phenomenon of problematization of youth, and to look beyond common sense or public perception on current social issues related to the youth in modern society. More importantly, youth problems can jeopardize the sustainable development of youth. [For example, education inequality (SDG4 Quality Education) and inadequate school-to-work transition (SDG8 Decent Work and Economic Growth) could impact on youth poverty (SDG1 No Poverty) as a result.] A broader and deeper understanding of various facets of problematization can inform how youth should be empowered to attain sustainable development in modern society.
outcome: Students will be able to capture the extent of youth problem in modern society.  Students will be able to gain a more intellectual understanding of the nature and possible causes of youth problems.  Students will be able to critically evaluate the public perception of social issues relating to the youth.  Student will be able to reflect on their life experiences as members of a younger population and their challenges of sustainable development in modern society.
syllabus: The core content of the course covers five areas in the study of youth problem.   The developmental discourse and the concept of social construction are examined to illustrate the emergence and the nature of the youth concept.     Biological, psychological and sociological views on the conceptualization of youth problem are introduced and compared, so as to illustrate the role and focus of social science, sociology in particular, in the study of youth problem.    Specific youth topics such as (1) educational inequality (SDG1 No poverty, SDG4 Quality Education), (2) precarious school-to-work transition and downward mobility (SDG1 No poverty, SDG8 Decent work and economic growth), (3) youth gangs and violence (SDG3 Good health and well-being), (4) exceptionalism and gender inequality (SDG5 Gender equality), (5) dating aggression and sexual health (SDG3 Good health and well-being, SDG5 Gender equality), (6) resistance of sexual minorities (SDG5 Gender equality); (7) digital media challenges (e.g. infodemics, SDG3 Good health and well-being), and (8) normalization of risk behaviors (e.g. addictions, SDG3 Good health and well-being), are explored to scrutinize the forms and the extent of problem encountered by youth in modern society.    Sociological concepts and perspectives, such as   rational choice theory, social stratification theory, feminism, subcultural theory,, media theories, and labeling perspective, are discussed to illuminate the social factors affecting the above-mentioned youth problems.     Postmodern perspectives and concepts, such as post-Fordism, post-materialism; risk society, risk assessment and individualization, are introduced to move beyond the modernity view and to offer a discussion on the recent emergence of new forms of social transformation and crisis faced by youth.

title: Environmentalism and Environmental Education
requirements:
UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130. 
Not for students majoring in EDU; not for CLED and ELED Majors; and students who have taken EDUC2130.
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: (UGEC2710 is double-coded with EDUC2130.) The course is aimed at preparing students as global and future citizens who not only have critical understandings of the environmental issues, but also the capabilities and attitudes to take an active role in tackling the issues and educating for the environment. This course is structured around key issues pertaining to environmentalism and environmental education, including climate changes, sustainability, green groups and environmental curriculum and teaching at schools. Using an issue-inquiry approach, course participants will be led to critically reflect on the issues from various perspectives: philosophical, scientific, social and educational. The different approaches to environmental education in the Western and Chinese communities will be explored in the contexts of eastern and western cultures. A field trip is included to provide experiential education in the environment.
outcome: At the end of this course, students will be able to:     understand the complexity of environmental issues as an interplay between science, politics, values, economy, education and social development;    critically understand key environmental issues at both local and global levels;    actively participate in the discourse and actions concerning environmental issues;    recognize different approaches to environmental education and critically analyze their strengths and constraints;    understand the relations between environmental education and cultural differences;    actively participate in environmental education both inside and outside the school systems;    appreciate and to live an environmentally-friendly lifestyle
syllabus: How do people start to care about the environment - a historical understanding of environmentalism and its definition    A framework for understanding environmental issues    Is climate change a myth or hoax - understanding the science behind and its limitations    Why don’t people take climate change seriously - consequences and solutions of climate change    What’s wrong with the countries – politics and the environment    What’s wrong with our society – modern capitalism and the environment    Is sustainable development a myth?    What’s wrong with human beings – environmental ethics?    What’s wrong with the environmental advocacy groups - myths of some environmental activities?    What's wrong with our education - aims and approaches of environmental education?    How do different countries approach environmental education –Hong Kong, China, Taiwan and others    Overview of issues related to environmental problems and environmental education    Field trip to a site related to current environmental issues in Hong Kong, such as North East development farmland, EcoPark, Fung Yuen butterfly convervation centre.

title: Cultural Perspectives of Chinese Medicine
requirements:
Not for students who have taken UGEA1881.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: The establishment and development of Chinese Medicine have been greatly inspired by traditional Chinese culture, including the ancient Chinese philosophy, religious doctrines and history. This course will provide the opportunity for students to possess a deeper understanding of the association between traditional Chinese culture and Chinese Medicine. The difference between Chinese and Western cultures will also be discussed.
outcome: 完成本科後，期望學生能夠︰- 提高對中華民族傳統文化的認知- 描述中華文化（包括中國古代哲學、宗教、文學、歷史、民族、飲食）與中醫學及識別中醫學的關係- 比較並指出中西醫學的異同- 評價中華文化在中醫學中的地位- 分析各種與中醫相關的文化現象與中醫學的連繫   (
syllabus: 講授內容（一）中醫的概念﹕中醫、中藥與中國文化概括介紹中國醫學的起源、形成、發展、學術特點及與中國傳統文化的密切關係，討論嶺南中醫藥文化以及中西醫的比較。（二）中醫藥與儒、釋、道家文化以及《易經》的關係簡述中醫藥文化與儒、釋、道三家以及易經的關係：儒家的仁、禮、中庸之道與中醫藥環環相扣，相互參照；釋家「醫方明」與中醫理論相互吸收和影響；道家學說不少與中醫理論類通，同樣強調人與大自然的關係和天人相應；《黃帝內經》對自然和人體的認識，及其辨證理論，一脈相承自《易經》。（三）文學與中醫以儒通醫。古代學者如陶潛、陸游、蘇軾、羅貫中、曹雪芹等都曾經行醫或有深厚的中醫造詣。   中醫不少著作是用詩、詞、歌、賦形式撰寫的，讀者容易記憶，文學著作亦有豐富的中醫內容。本節選讀唐詩、宋詞、紅樓夢、三國演義等文學著作，欣賞其中包含的中醫宇宙觀、生命觀、並討論其中所列舉的藥物，病案。（四）中醫理論之應用﹕飲食、養生之中醫文化從簡介舌診、臟腑辨證、君臣佐使組方原理，先讓學生認識中醫診治方法，再以飲食和養生兩方面闡述中華寶庫之一----中醫保健之道。食療：飲食養生，家居實用補藥，涼茶及保健湯水。養生：四季養生法，十二時辰養生法，休憩養生與七情養生。保健、養顏：按摩、穴位和藥膳。

title: Applied Ethics
requirements:
Not for Philosophy Majors; and students who have taken PHIL3253 or UGED2855. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: A survey of major moral debates that shows how philosophical thought can be brought to bear upon contemporary issues. This course will focus on such moral problems as arising from abortion, our treatment of animals, criminal punishment, death penalty, euthanasia, and sex. Students will learn normative ethical theories and reflect on how these theories can contribute to the resolution of the above-mentioned problems. Students will also be encouraged to develop their own judgments in a critical manner,
outcome: Understand the nature of applied ethics.    Recognize the characteristics and importance of some main problems of applied ethics.    Reflect on how to resolve these problems of applied ethics.    Understand each problem of applied ethics in its own right, and whether a particular problem must be resolved.    Identify the characteristics and value of ethical theories.    Explain and assess different moral stances in a perspicuous, non-doctrinaire way.
syllabus: (1-4) Core content, but topics to be covered in each area (2-4) will be decided by the course teacher.   1.      Introduction: What is ethics?  What is applied ethics? Theories of normative ethics and their relevance to applied ethics 2.      Bioethics (e.g., abortion, euthanasia) 3.      Ethics and the Nature (e.g., the welfare of animals, environmental ethics) 4.      Social and Political Issues (e.g., sexual morality, capital punishment)

description: (UGEC2853 is double-coded with GDRS2002.)  This course aims at an interdisciplinary approach to the study of human sexuality and culture. title: Animals and Society : A philosophical approach
requirements:
Not for Philosophy Major.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course examines the social issues of animal from the philosophical perspectives. What are the key differences humans and other animals? Is it ethical to raise and slaughter animals for food, conduct tests on, and buying or keeping animals as pets? How ought one to respond to unethical laws on animals? What are the social impacts of these actions? Students will develop an interdisciplinary perspective in the fields of animal studies, ethical theory, sociology and environmental philosophy by understanding how ancient and contemporary philosophers, sociologist, environmental scientists, ecologists, activists, and journalists have responded to key ethical questions concerning animal rights and its social implication. Topics to be discussed include: animal-machines, ethical meat eating, radical vegetarianism, and the evolution of pets.This course bears on several of the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). By transforming our attitude towards and relationship with animal, we enjoy the mental health benefits of a deepened appreciation of and connection with them (SDG#3 Good Health and Well-Being). By exploring the key difference between human and animals, we deepen our understand toward ourself and different species on earth (SDG#14 Life below water & SDG#15 Life on land). Finally, by reimagining our relationship with animal, we can envision for a just society in which all species could co-exist peacefully (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong institutions).
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to:  cite the major arguments in the current philosophical debates over the social and moral status of nonhuman animals, and understand the strengths and weakness of each;  recount the historical, scientific and cultural contexts of the debate;  discuss the broad range of animal exploitation and the moral issues that each form of it raises;  form a conclusion about the ethics of using animals and defend it with a strong, logical argument.  appreciate and enrich our emotional connection with animal  (SDG#3 Good Health and Well-Being).   deepen our understand towards ourselves and different species on earth (SDG#14 Life below water & SDG#15 Life on land).  envision for a just society in which all species could co-exist peacefully (SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong institutions).

title: Economic Reform and Social Impacts in China
requirements:
UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.
Not for Sociology Majors; and students who have taken GESC2118, SOCI2106 or UGEA2190.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2883 is double-coded with SOCI2106.)  Focusing on economic reforms, students will be taught the impetus of the institutional changes in China and how they affect the cultural, socioeconomic and organizational lives of Chinese people. Key social science concepts and theories like institution, ideology, socialism, marketization, social control, civil society, industrialization, urbanization, stratification, family, socialization, and specialized terms in China studies like guanxi (關係), danwei (單位), hukou (戶口), harmonious society, China dream, floating population, rural-urban divide, one/two child(ren) policy, will be introduced and discussed from an integrated perspective. After taking this course, students should be able to grasp the transformation and development in key areas of China, including economic reform, political system and change, rural and urban development, social inequality, family and marriage, cultural and ideological issues, as well as other institutional developments.
outcome: • Students are expected to grasp the basic knowledge about China’s major social institutions such as socialist market economy, party-state apparatus, stratification system, and lineage values. They should also be able to understand the evolution of these institutions over the past several decades. • Students should be able to understand how social scientists analyze and examine the formation, evolution, and influences of the major social institutions in contemporary China. They are expected to grasp the key concepts and theories developed from social scientists from sociology, economics, political science, etc. • Besides basic facts and social science perspectives, students are encouraged to critically evaluate some controversial topics from different angles through writing assignments. The topics will include key dilemmas in contemporary China regarding economic growth and social equality, state capacity and democracy, traditional culture and modernization, etc.
syllabus: Week 1: Introduction: Basic Information of the Chinese Society   * Provide basic information about the socio-economic characteristics of the contemporary China.  Week 2 & 3: China before Reform Era     * Provide information about the political systems, economic institutions, and social control mechanisms of China during Mao’s era.   Week 4 & 5: Economic Reform   * Provide information about the processes of economic reform since 1978, as well as its impact on the economic system afterwards.     Week 6 & 7 & 8: Impacts on the Political System and the Preservation of the Party-state  * Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the political system in China afterwards. Also, we will discuss the puzzle regarding the preservation of the Party-state despite the massive political reform.    Week 9: Impacts on Rural-urban Development and Migration  * Provide information about the differential impact of the economic reform on the urban and rural development, as well as the resultant great migration since then.     Week 10: Impacts on Social Stratification and Inequality   * Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the transition of the social stratification system and the enlarging social inequality.      Week 11 & 12: Impacts on Social Conflicts, Civil Society, and Social Control  * Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the growing social conflicts and the newly emerged social control mechanisms.    Week 13: Impacts on Population and Demographic Transition   * Provide information about the impact of the economic reform on the population and demographic patterns.       [*whether covering this depending on our schedule, because we may save some time for students to finish the final paper before the due date*]

title: Money, Land and Housing
requirements:
Not for Urban Studies Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: When money is fiat, land is scarce, housing becomes a good hedge of inflation. However, when housing is both an investment capital as well as a necessity, the city is split into an owner-renter dichotomy, with the former preferring an increase of housing prices but just the opposite for the latter. When the pendulum of housing price swings to one side, housing capital can result in negative equity, asset bubble, or even financial crisis. Swinging to the other end, housing can become unaffordable, even if public housing or subsidy can be provided. Decent living environment and sustainable community are the concerns of cities. This introduction course explores the reasons of the housing price fluctuations and the implications of the dichotomy on the city lives.
outcome: Explain the relationships between money, land and housing;    Understand factors determining land and housing prices;    Identify the effects of housing price fluctuations on financial stability and wealth inequality;    Appreciate the effect of monetary and land policies on housing affordability;    Draw implications from the owner-renter dichotomy on the housing policy; and    Analyse the sustainability issues of public housing and cooperative housing systems.
syllabus: The following topics are included in the course: PART I: Relationships between money, land and housing  Why housing can be a good hedge of inflation?  How does the monetary policy affect the housing market?  Why interest rate and inflation rate affect housing price?  Is high land price or restrictive land supply a cause of high housing price?  How does the housing policy affect the housing market? PART II: Social implications of housing issues  What is the owner-renter dichotomy of housing?  What are the implications of the housing dichotomy on our city lives?  Why housing can become unaffordable?  How does housing price fluctuation affect financial stability and wealth inequality?  Why are there housing cycles and housing bubbles?  What is property hegemony? PART III:  Is public housing or cooperative housing a solution?  A sustainable housing policy.

title: Belt and Road for Collaborative Modernization
requirements:
UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010. 
Not for Urban Studies Majors; and students who have taken URSP2010.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: (UGEC2917 is double-coded with URSP2010.)  The Belt and Road initiative (BRI) refers to the Silk Road Economic Belt and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road. It is a significant development strategy proposed by the Chinese Government spanning approximately 60 countries in Asia, Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa, with a total population of 4.4 billion. This initiative takes advantage of global transportation routes, core cities, and key ports to build international economic co-operation corridors. The effective operation and management of the BRI require collaboration among a broad range of disciplines comprising civil engineering, material science, government operations, economics and finance, social and political science, and environmental science. A critical and multi-disciplinary understanding of the BRI can provide insights into basic requirements, geopolitical impact, physical barriers, and sustainability potential of the infrastructural projects it proposes to undertake and help relevant stakeholders address large-scale and complex challenges in the lifecycle management of those infrastructure projects. This course involves forward-looking perspectives to assess, predict, influence and enhance the in/direct network effects and benefits of the BRI on the cities, urban systems and peoples of the Belt and Road region.
outcome: (1)    To explain the historical, economic and geopolitical background of the Belt and Road Initiative; (2)    To analyze economic, social, environmental, cultural and political forces, structures and processes associated with the Belt and Road Initiative; (3)    To evaluate the built environment and urban issues of Eurasian cities and how these may be improved by appropriate integration into the Belt and Road infrastructure; (4)    To apply Hong Kong’s world-class urban management practices to help the Belt and Road countries to maximize the benefits of network externality effects; (5)    To simulate and predict multi-scale spatial economic and urban outcomes of the Belt and Road infrastructure investments. (6)    To synthesize intercultural and global perspectives and to recommend ways to foster international cooperation, cultural diversity and integration.
syllabus: Introduction 1.       Globalization in Perspective: introduction of globalization as a term, process and ideology.     2.       Historical Silk Road: historical origins of the Silk Road; continuities and shifts in terms of Maritime Silk Road, interactions and encounters along the Silk Road.   Global Implications 3.       Geopolitical Shifts: branding and popularizing the Belt and Road Initiative; imperial histories and ambitions informing the initiative. 4.       Eastern and Western Perspectives: the opportunities and challenges arising from Belt and Road Initiative with reference to the European Recovery Program; the geopolitical theories of Alfred Mahan, Halford Mackinder and Henry Kissinger; the philosophy of Confucius and Taoists.   Facilities Connectivity 5.       Construction Management in BRI countries: risk management in international construction joint ventures and overseas development institute; large-scale transnational high-speed railway construction projects. 6.       Green and Sustainable Urbanization: In search of better livability in BRI cities: Liveability in dense and vertical cities; green finance; carbon auditing and carbon trading; green strategies for achieving sustainable development goals.   Unimpeded Trade 7.       Trading, Logistic, and Professional Service: Hong Kong as regional BRI centre for trading, logistic and professional services; manufacture shifting and upgrading experience in ASEAN economies. 8.       The Energy Market: energy market opportunities and uncertainties in Northeast, Southeast, Central Asia and Africa; global oil and gas markets; renewable and sustainable energy goals.   Financial Integration 9.       The Bond Market: infrastructure financing; international bond market and Hong Kong’s debt market; corporate social responsibility on Green Bond Issuance; the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank and the Silk Road Fund. 10.    International Settlement: currency wars and special drawing rights; consumerism and RMB internationalization; Hong Kong as the offshore RMB centre; the New Development Bank.   Regional Responses 11.    Middle East: geopolitics and energy nexus; religious and national concerns. 12.    Central and Eastern Europe: rail and maritime connectivities; integrating trade and resisting xenophobia. 13.    India: regional rivalry, economic integration and border disputes

title: Language and Society
requirements:
UGEC2925 is double-coded with LING2301.
Not for Bimodal Bilingual Studies; Linguistics Majors; and students who have taken LING2301 or UGEC1925. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix.
description: (UGEC2925 is double-coded with LING2301.) This course explores human language in the broader context of culture and society. How, for example, does one language community interacts with another language community in the multilingual world? Does language change and what are the processes involved? To what extent does the same language vary due to gender, power, status, and identity? How do men and women, people with higher and lower social status talk differently? How are these relationships reflected in the use of politeness markers and other linguistic devices? What are the implications of sociolinguistics on education and language planning? Through introducing students to major issues in sociolinguistic studies, students will be able to develop a better understanding of how language functions in societal contexts from a linguistic perspective. Discussions will also focus on common sociolinguistic phenomena in daily communication, with a specific emphasis on the use of various languages and dialects spoken in Hong Kong. Exploring these topics will enhance students’ awareness of language as a cultural phenomenon and sharpen their sensitivity to the nuances of language use in the context of a multilingual world, with special reference to the sociolinguistic context of the Greater China area.
outcome: Students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes:  Discuss the social factors that influence language use;  Identify the key issues in sociolinguistics and discuss these issues using the appropriate terminology;  Identify common sociolinguistic phenomena in daily communication settings;  Conduct basic analysis of sociolinguistic phenomena using the concepts learned in the course.

title: Thinking sustainability: Health and Global Challenges
components:
Discussion
Lecture
Interactive Tutorial
Web-enhanced Teaching
requirements:
Not for Public Health Majors.
Co-requisite: Any course with "UGFH" or "UGFN" as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: In this course, we will discuss the direct and indirect health consequences related to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the United Nations and analyze the wider socioeconomic dimensions of these topics. After the pandemic we faced, we realized that a health crisis will have implications beyond the health sector and development must balance social, economic and environmental sustainability. It is therefore important for us, as global citizens, to recognize the issues related and understand how we can take part in this. Traditionally, health indicators have been an important aspect of development indices and health is a foundation of societies. Therefore, our course aims to discuss SDGs through the lens of health, by providing an overview on how the current global challenges on sustainable development impacts the population health and encourage students to look for solutions. We will cover the health-related SDGs by blended learning, including 2. Zero Hunger where we will discuss malnutrition, 3. Good Health and Well-being where we will discuss road injuries, infrastructure and management, 5. Gender Equality where we will discuss intimate partner violence, 6. Clean Water and Sanitation where we will discuss water safety and supply, 8. Decent Work and Economic Growth where we will discuss labor rights and occupational injuries, 11. Sustainable Cities and Communities where we will discuss impacts on health, socioeconomics and environment of inadequate housing and poor living environment, 13. Climate Action where we will discuss Climate-related disasters and disaster risks, and 16. Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions where we will discuss concept and impact of peace and justice on health. Through face-to-face tutorials and case-based discussions, we will discuss selected topics in greater details, including the road safety aspects of Goal 3 “Good health and well-being”, the protection of workers from work-related injuries in Goal 8 “Decent work and economic growth”, the disaster risks in modern developments in Goal 13 “Climate action”, and how to educate the younger generation on the promotion of peace in Goal 16 “Peace, justice and strong institutions”. Development of modern societies and the interaction between humans and environment will be discussed, and through the advocacy framework we will discuss the current challenges related which draw immense global attention, and allow students to exchange interdisciplinary ideas, identify the challenges we are facing and propose advocacy campaign in hope to identify and deliver solutions locally and internationally.

title: Islam in Hong Kong
requirements:
Not for History Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
description: This course aims to address the historical development and localisation of Islam in the cultural context of Hong Kong. It firstly introduces the basic knowledge of Islam and Islamic culture worldwide; and the prominent cultural and social position of Islam in the contemporary globalised world. It then applies Hong Kong as a case study to examine the historical evolution of various Muslim communities of Hong Kong, such as Indian, Pakantsian, Indonesian, African and Chinese Muslim communities. It also discusses how these Muslim communities interfaced with each other and integrated with the local society. By establishing a more inclusive and diversified understanding of the local Muslim community, this course responds to the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities. Meanwhile, it pinpoints local Muslim communities' challenges in the current globalised world. Islam is one of the most important religions in the contemporary world, which is also a key to achieving a safe and peaceful global environment; therefore, this course also echoes the UN Sustainable Development Goals #16 'Reduced Inequalities'.

title: Museum and Heritage
requirements:
Not for History Majors; and students who have taken HIST3441. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course reviews the historical development of concepts and theories related to museums and cultural heritage. It introduces diversified definitions of museums and heritage in the contemporary. Through selected case studies and field trips, it demonstrates the operations of museums and heritage sites; and analyses their social roles in modern society. It aligns with the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, which emphasises making more inclusive and sustainable cities and communities. It also reviews the historical evolution of international conventions related to museums and heritage outlines how global and regional cooperation, such as the development of UNESCO World Heritage, is vital for sustainable heritage conservation and management. It directly responds to the UN Sustainable Development Goals #17, 'Revitalise the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development which suggests that successful global development requires inclusive and international partnerships.
outcome: Students should understand core concepts and theories related to museums and heritage in the contemporary world.    Students should learn about the historical evolution of social and cultural roles of museums and heritage, especially in the social context of the East Asian region. They shall further develop their capacity to review the social functions of museums and heritage in the rapidly changing contemporary society. It shall help students pinpoint the core values of the UN Sustainable Development Goals #11 'Sustainable Cities and Communities, which emphasises making more inclusive and sustainable cities and communities.    Students shall be able to outline the importance of international and regional cooperation on issues related to heritage conservation, such as the establishment of UNESCO and the Modus Operandi of the UNESCO World Heritage. It allows students to recognise the importance of global solidarity in achieving a successful and sustainable international development emphasised by the UN Sustainable Development Goals #17, 'Revitalise the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development.
syllabus: Section 1: Concepts and theories related to museums and heritage 1. The origin of the museum and its historical development. 2. The concepts and definitions of cultural heritage and their historical evolution. 3. Understanding and interpreting cultural heritage in the East Asian context.   Section 2: The social roles of museums and heritage and their public engagement 1. The transformation of the social roles of museums and heritage. 2. The educational functions of museums and heritage: how museums and heritage sites could collaborate to provide a culturally diversified learning experience for different society stakeholders, including children, the elderly, and people with physical and mental disabilities. 3. The social inclusion of museums and heritage: how museums and heritage could help motivate local societies' sustainable development and address the value of social justice worldwide. 4. The reuse and revitalisation of heritage in modern society.   Section 3: Achieving sustainable heritage conservation and management through International and regional cooperation 1. title: The Peoples of Hong Kong in History
requirements:
Not for History Majors. 
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: Being one of the most cosmopolitan cities in the World, Hong Kong encompasses people of different racial, ethnic and social backgrounds, that attributes to Hong Kong’s hybridity and diversity. This course introduces students to the history of Hong Kong by looking closely at the many varied peoples in Hong Kong. Hong Kong, the gateway to China and a former British colony with dominant Chinese population, how the life, experience and identity of different races, ethnicities and classes differs? What roles did they play in the rise of Hong Kong from a fishing village to a global hub for opportunity? How did their different stories together turn Hong Kong into a cultural melting pot? This course is relevant to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly in the area of SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth, SDG#10 Reducing Inequalities and SDG#11 Sustainable Cities and Communities.

title: History of Hong Kong
requirements:
Not for History Majors; and students who have taken GESC2150, GLBS3406. HIST2500 or UGEC3542.
Co-requisite: Any course with “UGFH” or “UGFN” as prefix
description: This course introduces the history of Hong Kong from a British colony to the Special Administrative Region of China. It covers major events and issues of Hong Kong, emphasizing the development of political system, social structure and economic pattern, and evaluate the role of Hong Kong in modern China, in the Asian-Pacific region and in the world. The course critically examines how colonial governance and Sino-British relations affected Hong Kong, offering students a multi-perspective in understanding how Hong Kong has becomes what it is today. This course is relevant to three Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly in the area of SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth by looking at the development of Hong Kong from an entrepôt to a global financial centre, SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities by looking at how Hong Kong evolved from a society of racial segregation to social inclusiveness, and SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions by looking at the public policy in promoting social reform and social justice.
outcome: Have a better understanding on the history of Hong Kong.  Recognize and critically analyze how and why various contexts affecting the development of Hong Kong.  Identify and examine the economic roles and positions of Hong Kong in modern Chinese history and in a global context (SDG#8 Decent Work and Economic Growth).  Articulate fair evaluation on issues surrounding the daily life in Hong Kong (e.g. inequalities in economic and political power, housing problem, etc.) after understanding their origins, and able to reflect on how to promote social reform and justice based on the experience of the past (SDG#10 Reduced Inequalities and SDG#16 Peace, Justice and Social Institution).
